channel.title: math.GM updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: math.GM updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Surfaces of coordinate finite II-type
item.description: arXiv:2005.05120v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: In this article, we study the class of surfaces of revolution in the 3-dimensional Euclidean space $E^{3}$ with nonvanishing Gauss curvature whose position vector $\boldsymbol{x}$ satisfies the condition $\Delta^{II}\boldsymbol{x}=A\boldsymbol{x}$, where $A$ is a square matrix of order 3 and $\Delta^{II}$ denotes the Laplace operator of the second fundamental form $II$ of the surface. We show that a surface of revolution satisfying the preceding relation is a catenoid or part of a sphere.
item.dc:creator: Hassan Al-Zoubi, Mutaz Al-Sabbagh, Tareq Hamadneh

item.title: On necessary conditions for a friend of 20
item.description: arXiv:2409.04451v3 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Does $20$ have a friend? Or is it a solitary number? A folklore conjecture asserts that $20$ has no friends i.e. it is a solitary number. In this article, we prove that, a friend $N$ of $20$ is of the form $N=2\cdot5^{2a}\cdot m^2$, with $(3,m)=(7,m)=1$ and it has atleast six distinct prime divisors. Also, we prove that $N$ must be greater than $2\cdot 10^{12}$. Furthermore, we show that $\Omega(N)\geq 2\omega(N)+6a-5$ and if $\Omega(m)\leq K$ then $N< 10\cdot 6^{(2^{K-2a+3}-1)^2}$, where $\Omega(n)$ and $\omega(n)$ denote the total number of prime divisors and the number of distinct prime divisors of the integer $n$ respectively. In addition, we deduce that, not all exponents of odd prime divisors of friend $N$ of $20$ are congruent to $-1$ modulo $f$, where $f$ is the order of $5$ in $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^\times$ such that $3\mid f$ and $p$ is a prime congruent to $1$ modulo $6$. Also, we propose necessary upper bounds for all prime divisors of friends of 20.
item.dc:creator: Tapas Chatterjee, Sagar Mandal, Sourav Mandal
